trans-unit.source: Azure AD is the identity provider, responsible for verifying the identity of users and applications that exist in an organization’s directory, and ultimately issuing security tokens upon successful authentication of those users and applications.
trans-unit.target: Azure AD is the identity provider, responsible for verifying the identity of users and applications that exist in an organization’s directory, and ultimately issuing security tokens upon successful authentication of those users and applications.

trans-unit.source: An application that wants to outsource authentication to Azure AD must be registered in Azure AD, which registers and uniquely identifies the app in the directory.

trans-unit.source: Developers can use the open source Azure AD authentication libraries to make authentication easy by handling the protocol details for you.
trans-unit.target: Developers can use the open source Azure AD authentication libraries to make authentication easy by handling the protocol details for you.

trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Azure Active Directory Authentication Libraries</linkText><title></title> for more information.

trans-unit.source: • Once a user has been authenticated, the application must validate the user’s security token to ensure that authentication was successful for the intended parties.
trans-unit.target: • Once a user has been authenticated, the application must validate the user’s security token to ensure that authentication was successful for the intended parties.

trans-unit.source: Developers can use the provided authentication libraries to handle validation of any token from Azure AD, including JSON Web Tokens (JWT) or SAML 2.0.
trans-unit.target: Developers can use the provided authentication libraries to handle validation of any token from Azure AD, including JSON Web Tokens (JWT) or SAML 2.0.

trans-unit.source: Azure AD supports the OAuth 2.0 and OpenID Connect standards that make extensive use of bearer tokens, including bearer tokens represented as JWTs.
trans-unit.target: Azure AD supports the OAuth 2.0 and OpenID Connect standards that make extensive use of bearer tokens, including bearer tokens represented as JWTs.

trans-unit.source: A bearer token is a lightweight security token that grants the “bearer” access to a protected resource.
trans-unit.target: A bearer token is a lightweight security token that grants the “bearer” access to a protected resource.

trans-unit.source: In this sense, the “bearer” is any party that can present the token.
trans-unit.target: In this sense, the “bearer” is any party that can present the token.

trans-unit.source: Though a party must first authenticate with Azure AD to receive the bearer token, if the required steps are not taken to secure the token in transmission and storage, it can be intercepted and used by an unintended party.
trans-unit.target: Though a party must first authenticate with Azure AD to receive the bearer token, if the required steps are not taken to secure the token in transmission and storage, it can be intercepted and used by an unintended party.

trans-unit.source: While some security tokens have a built-in mechanism for preventing unauthorized parties from using them, bearer tokens do not have this mechanism and must be transported in a secure channel such as transport layer security (HTTPS).
trans-unit.target: While some security tokens have a built-in mechanism for preventing unauthorized parties from using them, bearer tokens do not have this mechanism and must be transported in a secure channel such as transport layer security (HTTPS).

trans-unit.source: If a bearer token is transmitted in the clear, a man-in the middle attack can be used by a malicious party to acquire the token and use it for an unauthorized access to a protected resource.
trans-unit.target: If a bearer token is transmitted in the clear, a man-in the middle attack can be used by a malicious party to acquire the token and use it for an unauthorized access to a protected resource.

trans-unit.source: The same security principles apply when storing or caching bearer tokens for later use.
trans-unit.target: The same security principles apply when storing or caching bearer tokens for later use.

trans-unit.source: Always ensure that your application transmits and stores bearer tokens in a secure manner.
trans-unit.target: Always ensure that your application transmits and stores bearer tokens in a secure manner.

trans-unit.source: For more security considerations on bearer tokens, see <linkText>RFC 6750 Section 5</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more security considerations on bearer tokens, see <linkText>RFC 6750 Section 5</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Application ID URI: The identifier for an application.
trans-unit.target: Application ID URI: The identifier for an application.

trans-unit.target: This value is sent to Azure AD during authentication to indicate which application the caller wants a token for.

trans-unit.target: Additionally, this value is included in the token so that the application knows it was the intended target.

trans-unit.target: Reply URL and Redirect URI: In the case of a web API or web application, the Reply URL is the location to which Azure AD will send the authentication response, including a token if authentication was successful.

trans-unit.source: Provisioning becomes clearer when you understand that there are two categories of applications that can be developed and integrated with Azure AD:
trans-unit.target: Provisioning becomes clearer when you understand that there are two categories of applications that can be developed and integrated with Azure AD:

trans-unit.source: Single tenant application: A single tenant application is intended for use in one organization.
trans-unit.target: Single tenant application: A single tenant application is intended for use in one organization.

trans-unit.source: These are typically line-of-business (LoB) applications written by an enterprise developer.
trans-unit.target: These are typically line-of-business (LoB) applications written by an enterprise developer.

trans-unit.source: A single tenant application only needs to be accessed by users in one directory, and as a result, it only needs to be provisioned in one directory.
trans-unit.target: A single tenant application only needs to be accessed by users in one directory, and as a result, it only needs to be provisioned in one directory.

trans-unit.source: These applications are typically registered by a developer in the organization.
trans-unit.target: These applications are typically registered by a developer in the organization.

trans-unit.source: Multi-tenant application: A multi-tenant application is intended for use in many organizations, not just one organization.
trans-unit.target: Multi-tenant application: A multi-tenant application is intended for use in many organizations, not just one organization.

trans-unit.source: These are typically software-as-a-service (SaaS) applications written by an independent software vendor (ISV).
trans-unit.target: These are typically software-as-a-service (SaaS) applications written by an independent software vendor (ISV).

trans-unit.source: Multi-tenant applications need to be provisioned in each directory where they will be used, which requires user or administrator consent to register them.
trans-unit.target: Multi-tenant applications need to be provisioned in each directory where they will be used, which requires user or administrator consent to register them.

trans-unit.source: This consent process starts when an application has been registered in the directory and is given access to the Graph API or perhaps another web API.
trans-unit.target: This consent process starts when an application has been registered in the directory and is given access to the Graph API or perhaps another web API.

trans-unit.source: When a user or administrator from a different organization signs up to use the application, they are presented with a dialog that displays the permissions the application requires.
trans-unit.target: When a user or administrator from a different organization signs up to use the application, they are presented with a dialog that displays the permissions the application requires.

trans-unit.source: The user or administrator can then consent to the application, which gives the application access to the stated data, and finally registers the application in their directory.
trans-unit.target: The user or administrator can then consent to the application, which gives the application access to the stated data, and finally registers the application in their directory.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Overview of the Consent Framework</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Overview of the Consent Framework</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Some additional considerations arise when developing a multi-tenant application instead of a single tenant application.
trans-unit.target: Some additional considerations arise when developing a multi-tenant application instead of a single tenant application.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you are making your application available to users in multiple directories, you need a mechanism to determine which tenant they’re in.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you are making your application available to users in multiple directories, you need a mechanism to determine which tenant they’re in.

trans-unit.source: A single tenant application only needs to look in its own directory for a user, while a multi-tenant application needs to identify a specific user from all the directories in Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: A single tenant application only needs to look in its own directory for a user, while a multi-tenant application needs to identify a specific user from all the directories in Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: To accomplish this task, Azure AD provides a common authentication endpoint where any multi-tenant application can direct sign-in requests, instead of a tenant-specific endpoint.
trans-unit.target: To accomplish this task, Azure AD provides a common authentication endpoint where any multi-tenant application can direct sign-in requests, instead of a tenant-specific endpoint.

trans-unit.source: This endpoint is https://login.microsoftonline.com/common for all directories in Azure AD, whereas a tenant-specific endpoint might be https://login.microsoftonline.com/contoso.onmicrosoft.com.
trans-unit.target: This endpoint is https://login.microsoftonline.com/common for all directories in Azure AD, whereas a tenant-specific endpoint might be https://login.microsoftonline.com/contoso.onmicrosoft.com.

trans-unit.source: The common endpoint is especially important to consider when developing your application because you’ll need the necessary logic to handle multiple tenants during sign-in, sign-out, and token validation.
trans-unit.target: The common endpoint is especially important to consider when developing your application because you’ll need the necessary logic to handle multiple tenants during sign-in, sign-out, and token validation.

trans-unit.source: If you are currently developing a single tenant application but want to make it available to many organizations, you can easily make changes to the application and its configuration in Azure AD to make it multi-tenant capable.
trans-unit.target: If you are currently developing a single tenant application but want to make it available to many organizations, you can easily make changes to the application and its configuration in Azure AD to make it multi-tenant capable.

trans-unit.source: In addition, Azure AD uses the same signing key for all tokens in all directories, whether you are providing authentication in a single tenant or multi-tenant application.
trans-unit.target: In addition, Azure AD uses the same signing key for all tokens in all directories, whether you are providing authentication in a single tenant or multi-tenant application.
